newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia aluminium makers eye emission cuts.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia aluminium makers eye emission cuts.

text.p: Australia's aluminium makers said on Thursday they would work toward making further reductions in harmful greenhouse gas emissions.

"The Australian aluminium industry is working together to deal with the greenhouse issue," Ian Edwards, managing director of Capral Aluminium Ltd and president of the Australian Aluminium Council said in a speech to business and government leaders on Greenhouse emissions.
The council represents Alcoa of Australia Ltd, Capral, Comalco Ltd and Tomago Aluminium Ltd, which in total produce about 1.3 million tonnes of aluminium a year.
Edwards said the industry has already reduced greenhouse emissions by over 14 percent per tonne of aluminium since 1990.

"This is equivalent to a total reduction in greenhouse gas emissions of 10 percent and has been achieved even though production of aluminium has increased by over four percent in the same period," Edwards said.
Under a so-called "Greenhouse Challenge" pact with the federal government, Edwards said aluminium makers aim to reduce CO2 equivalents per tonne by a further seven percent by the end of the decade.
The aluminium industry is Australia's largest industrial user of electricity, Edwards said.
A spokesman for Alcoa said advances in technology have enabled aluminium smelters to use less power to produce aluminium
Most electricity in Australia is generated from coal, meaning that gains in energy efficiency would contribute to the abatement of greenhouse gas emissions.
